### [Marah is a contained substance]{.smallcaps} {#contained-substance-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-containedfluid-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_containedfluid_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "is substance in a container$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(_located\\-substance)"), "key", "no"),
         status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "experiencer_container"), "key", status),
         status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(substance.fullness.level)"), "key", status),
         MP_GLOSS = str_replace_all(MP_GLOSS, "\\sbe channelled(?!\\*)", " *be channelled*"))

mapping_containedfluid_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'is substance in a container$') %>% left_join(mapping_containedfluid_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_containedfluid_token_stats)
```

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_containedfluid_token, 'impeding flowing', lu_var = "MP", gloss_var = "MP_GLOSS")`

- source of the liquid &rarr; cause of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_containedfluid_token_stats, '^cause of anger')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_containedfluid_token, 'cause of anger', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_containedfluid_token, '^cause of anger', lu_var = "MP", gloss_var = "MP_GLOSS")`

- substance becomes hard &rarr; intense anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_containedfluid_token_stats, 'hard$')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_containedfluid_token, 'hard$', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_containedfluid_token, 'hard$')`

It is obvious that the corpus dataset has much greater number of linguistic types and mappings compared to the lexical dataset. Despite this difference, the metaphor in both datasets equally focuses on the externalisation/expression of anger since the metaphorical expressions of the mapping for this aspect is the most productive.

### [Marah is a fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} {#animal-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-animal-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_animal_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "animal$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "anger_restrained-entity"), "key", "no"),
         status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "experiencer/other-emotion_restraining-entity"), "key", status))
mapping_animal_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_animal_token)
mapping_animal_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'animal$') %>% left_join(mapping_animal_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_animal_token_stats)
```


This metaphor is in the top-two salient metaphors across the two approaches but differs in its main meaning focus. In the lexical dataset ([§\@ref(animal-typebased)](#animal-typebased)), the predominant expressions highlight the aggressive behaviour of the animal (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_stats, 'aggressive')`). In the corpus dataset, the expressions predominantly evoke mapping for restraining the animal (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_token_stats, 'restraining')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_animal_token, 'restraining')`); this mapping is the least prominent in the lexical dataset (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_stats, 'restraining')`).

- restrained, fierce animal &rarr; anger

- restraining entity &rarr; experiencer (or other states)

- restraining the animal &rarr;; regulating anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_token_stats, 'restraining')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_animal_token, 'restraining', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r str_replace_all(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_animal_token, 'restraining'), fixed("controlable"), "controllable")`

- unleashing a captive &rarr; expressing and losing control over anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_token_stats, 'unleashing')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_animal_token, 'unleashing', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_animal_token, 'unleashing')`

- aggressive animal behaviour &rarr; aggressive anger behaviour  (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_token_stats, 'aggressive anger')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_animal_token, 'aggressive anger', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_animal_token, 'aggressive anger')`

- being attacked by animal &rarr; experiencing effect of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_animal_token_stats, 'attacked')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_animal_token, 'attacked', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_animal_token, 'attacked')`

The difference in the main meaning focus of the same metaphor between the two approaches indicate that combining the different methods enriches the nuance in the highlighted aspect of a metaphor.

### [Marah is fire]{.smallcaps} {#fire-tokenbased}


Similar to the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor, the [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor is prominent in Indonesian in the lexical ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-type-based)](#metaphor-table-type-based)) and corpus-based datasets ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based)).

- fire &rarr; anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_fire_token_stats, 'anger is fire$')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'anger is fire$', lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_fire_token, 'anger is fire$')`)

- burning/burnt object &rarr; angry person

- fire intensity &rarr; anger level

- the increased degree of fire &rarr; the increased degree of anger intensity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_fire_token_stats, 'highest')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'highest', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_fire_token, 'highest')`

- igniting fire &rarr; causing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_fire_token_stats, 'causing')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'causing', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_fire_token, 'causing')`

- potential open fire &rarr; latent intensity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_fire_token_stats, 'latent')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'latent', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_fire_token, 'latent')`

- fire going out &rarr; ceasing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_fire_token_stats, 'ceasing')`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'ceasing', lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_fire_token, 'ceasing')`

The [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor in the two approaches equally focuses on the intensity aspect, particularly the increased intensity of the fire given its greatest number of metaphorical expressions compared to the other mappings. However, if the token frequency of the mapping is considered, the [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor predominantly captures the cause of anger (token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_fire_token, 'causing', lu_output = FALSE)`).

### [Marah is weapon]{.smallcaps} {#weapon-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-weapon-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_weapon_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "weapon$")) %>%

```

The [weapon]{.smallcaps} metaphor is only identified in the corpus approach. The main meaning focus is directing/targeting anger to the wrongdoer or other people. In terms of the token frequency of the mapping, the causation mapping is the most predominant. Despite the highest token of the causation mapping, its linguistic manifestation is less varied compared to the targeting anger mapping, having diverse types despite its lower token frequency.

- the wrongdoer or other people &rarr; target of expression of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_weapon_token_stats, "target of expression of anger")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_weapon_token, "target of expression of anger", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_weapon_token, "target of expression of anger")`

- pulling the trigger &rarr; causing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_weapon_token_stats, "pulling the trigger")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_weapon_token, "pulling the trigger", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_weapon_token, "pulling the trigger")`
  
- punishing with the weapon &rarr; retribution/avenge to wrongdoing (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_weapon_token_stats, "punishing|avenging")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_weapon_token, "punishing|avenging", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_weapon_token, "punishing|avenging")`
  
- weapon &rarr; anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_weapon_token_stats, "^anger is weapon$")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_weapon_token, "^anger is weapon$", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_weapon_token, "^anger is weapon$")`
  
- redirecting weapon to constructive goal &rarr; channelling anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_weapon_token_stats, "constructive")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_weapon_token, "constructive", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_weapon_token, "constructive")`

The last mapping refers to a non-prototypical model of anger, namely "constructive use" of anger [@holland_cognitive_1987, 215].

### [Marah is an adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps} {#adversary-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-adversary-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_adversary_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "adversary$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "fighter[12]"), "key", "no"),
         MP = str_replace_all(MP, "\\bnnode\\b", "node"))
mapping_adversary_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_adversary_token)
mapping_adversary_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'adversary$') %>% left_join(mapping_adversary_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_adversary_token_stats)

opponent_frame_token <- count(filter(marah, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "adversary$")), SFRAME, sort = TRUE)
opponent_frame_type <- arrange(summarise(group_by(filter(marah, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "adversary$")), SFRAME), n_lu = n_distinct(LU)), desc(n_lu))
opponent_victim_token <- count(filter(marah, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "adversary$")), NOTES, sort = TRUE) %>% 
  mutate(NOTES = replace(NOTES, is.na(NOTES), "self as victim of anger"))
```

The [adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps} metaphor is absent in the lexical dataset. The metaphorical expressions evoke the [physical combat]{.smallcaps} frame (type=`r pull(slice_max(opponent_frame_type, order_by = n_lu), n_lu)`; token=`r pull(slice_max(opponent_frame_token, order_by = n), n)`). However, closer investigation on the context of the data reveal that the hostile encounter is not always between the anger-adversary and the self/experiencer. Construing anger as an adversary includes being the adversary for external, non-self entity (predominantly victim of a directed anger) (`r sum(pull(filter(opponent_victim_token, str_detect(NOTES, 'external|state')), n))` instances of the total `r sum(opponent_victim_token$n)` tokens of this metaphor). There are `r unlist(tally(filter(opponent_victim_token, str_detect(NOTES, 'external|state|^anger', negate = TRUE)), n))` instances where the victim is the self. This variation in the combatant of anger indicates that the adversarial nature of anger can not only endanger the experiencers but also social entities around them. 

- giving in/losing &rarr; experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, "losing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, "losing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_adversary_token, "losing")`

- combating opponent &rarr; attempt to control anger (e.g., fighting, confronting) (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, "combating")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, "combating", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_adversary_token, "combating")`

- being protected from the opponent &rarr; evading anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, "evading")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, "evading", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_adversary_token, "evading")`

- winning over the opponent &rarr; managing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, "winning")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, "winning", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_adversary_token, "winning")`

- potential danger of the opponent &rarr; potential effect of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, "^potential")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, "^potential", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_adversary_token, "^potential")`
  
The main meaning foci of the metaphor are the mappings [managing anger is winning over the opponent]{.smallcaps} and [experiencing anger is giving in/losing to anger]{.smallcaps}. Both share the same number of types though the former is lexically more varied given its token frequency than the latter. That is, `r get_metaphor_mapping_ttr(mapping_adversary_token_stats, 'winning')`% of the `r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, 'winning')` tokens for [managing anger is winning over the opponent]{.smallcaps} are expressed by different types [`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, 'winning')`]. Meanwhile, only `r get_metaphor_mapping_ttr(mapping_adversary_token_stats, 'losing')`% of the `r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_adversary_token, 'losing')` tokens for [experiencing anger is giving in/losing to anger]{.smallcaps} are expressed by different types [`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_adversary_token_stats, 'losing')`].

### [Intensity is verticality/height]{.smallcaps} {#verticality-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-verticality-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_verticality_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "verticality$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(_vertical.entity|_verticality.scale)"), "key", "no"))
mapping_verticality_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_verticality_token)
mapping_verticality_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'verticality$') %>% left_join(mapping_verticality_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_verticality_token_stats)
verticality_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("verticality$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [intensity is verticality/height]{.smallcaps} is shared between the lexical (rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'verticality$')`) and corpus approaches (rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'verticality$')`) in the top-10 ranking. This metaphor is based on LUs referring to several MN frame families, namely [being at a high location]{.smallcaps}, [(caused) upward/downward motion]{.smallcaps}, and [scale]{.smallcaps}, which is incorporated as a frame role in the [verticality]{.smallcaps} frame. The predominant frame in the metaphor is the [(caused) upward motion]{.smallcaps} frame (type=`r sum(filter(verticality_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'upward'))$type)`; token=`r sum(filter(verticality_frame_stats, str_detect(frames, 'upward'))$n)`). The [verticality]{.smallcaps} metaphor has `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_type", "verticality$")` types of metaphorical expression evoking `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_mapping", "verticality$"))` mappings. Together, all these frames and their LUs highlight the dynamics of the intensity as movement or position of the [anger]{.smallcaps}-entity along the vertical scale.

- vertical entity &rarr; anger

- entity being at/going up to/reaching the highest end of the scale &rarr; highest intensity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_verticality_token_stats, "^highest")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_verticality_token, "^highest", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_verticality_token, "^highest")`

- (caused) upward motion &rarr; increasing intensity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_verticality_token_stats, "caused")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_verticality_token, "caused", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_verticality_token, "caused")`

- low on the scale &rarr; reduced intensity of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_verticality_token_stats, "reduced")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_verticality_token, "reduced", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_verticality_token, "reduced")`

- verticality scale &rarr; intensity of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_verticality_token_stats, "is verticality scale$")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_verticality_token, "is verticality scale$", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_verticality_token, "is verticality scale$")`)

- balancing the scale &rarr; maintaining anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_verticality_token_stats, "balancing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_verticality_token, "balancing", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_verticality_token, "balancing")`)

The two predominant mappings refer to (i) an entity reaching/being at the peak of the scale and (ii) the lifted position of the entity along the scale, without implying whether such upward motion of the anger-entity would reach the peak.

The LUs of the metaphor evoke a variety of frames. Some of them are within the [motion impediment]{.smallcaps} frame family, namely [confinement]{.smallcaps} and [barrier]{.smallcaps} (sub-cases of the [motion-affecting properties of the landscape]{.smallcaps} frame), and [restraints]{.smallcaps} (a sub-case of the [motion-affecting objects]{.smallcaps} frame). Another frame is [hiding]{.smallcaps}, especially the LUs referring to enclosing/encompassing the experiencer (that is generically related to the [containment/bounded-region]{.smallcaps} frame). Several other tokens of LUs evoke the [motion with respect to an undesirable entity]{.smallcaps} frame. Semantically, the metaphor highlights the undesirability and difficulty of being in a state of anger.

- increased pressure of the substance to the container &rarr; increased intensity (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_pressurised_token_stats, "increased pressure")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_pressurised_token, "increased pressure", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_pressurised_token, "increased pressure")`

One interesting difference between the [pressurised substance in a container]{.smallcaps} metaphor from the two datasets is that in the lexical approach, the main meaning focus is on the (caused) increased pressure and substance. In contrast, the corpus dataset focuses on the loss of control, which is conceptualised as the explosion of the pressurised substance (see the greatest number of types and tokens for the explosion mapping). Moreover, the attempt at control aspect is not attested in the lexical approach but only in the corpus approach (the fourth mapping).

### [Marah is possession]{.smallcaps} {#possession-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-possession-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_possession_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "possession")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_possession_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_possession_token)
mapping_possession_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'possession') %>% left_join(mapping_possession_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_possession_token_stats)
possession_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("possession", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP") %>% mutate(frame_category = if_else(str_detect(frames, "(forced|propulsion)"), "affected motion", "possession"))
possession_framefamily_stats <- possession_frame_stats %>% group_by(frame_category) %>% summarise(n = sum(n), type = sum(type), .groups = "drop") %>% mutate(perc_n = round(n/sum(n) * 100), perc_type = round(type/sum(type) * 100))
```

This metaphor is a sub-case of the generic [object event-structure]{.smallcaps} metaphor, namely [attributed states are possessed objects]{.smallcaps} [@lakoff_philosophy_1999, 195-196, 198]. It realises `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'possession'))` types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'possession')` tokens) manifesting `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_mapping', 'possession'))` mappings. The key mappings in the metaphor are (i) anger is the possession and (ii) angry person (or non-self-entity, such as utterances, events, or even God) is the possessor or carrier of the object. The entailed mappings from these two are as follows:

- having/keeping/carrying possession &rarr; feeling/experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_possession_token_stats, "keeping")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_possession_token, "keeping", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_possession_token, "keeping")`

- obtaining an object &rarr; being scolded (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_possession_token_stats, "scolded")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_possession_token, "scolded", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_possession_token, "scolded")`

- giving object &rarr; expressing anger to others (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_possession_token_stats, "expressing anger to others")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_possession_token, "expressing anger to others", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_possession_token, "expressing anger to others")`

- losing/giving away possession &rarr; not experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_possession_token_stats, "not experiencing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_possession_token, "not experiencing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_possession_token, "not experiencing")`

Most of the metaphorical expressions (i.e., `r pull(filter(possession_framefamily_stats, frame_category == "possession"), perc_n)`% of the metaphor token) evoke the [possession]{.smallcaps} frame family (type=`r pull(filter(possession_framefamily_stats, frame_category == "possession"), type)`; token=`r pull(filter(possession_framefamily_stats, frame_category == "possession"), n)`), namely [possession]{.smallcaps} itself and [transfer scenario]{.smallcaps}, the roles of which also make use of the [gain possession]{.smallcaps}, [lose possession]{.smallcaps}, and [giving]{.smallcaps}. The remaining tokens are LUs evoking frames within the [affected motion]{.smallcaps} family such as [bringing]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *__membawa__ [marah]{.smallcaps}* '_carry_ anger') and [object propulsion]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *__membuang__ [marah]{.smallcaps}* '_throw away_ anger').

The inference from keeping the possession refers to the experience of anger, and when the possessor/self loses the anger-possession, the self no longer feels angry. The sentential context of the pattern evoking the gaining and giving the possession is not necessarily causing the recipient to become angry akin to the giver. Instead, gaining/getting or being given anger from the possessor means that the recipient becomes the target of the angry person presumably because of the wrongdoing of the recipient/target of transfer (i.e., the recipient becomes the target of scolding, which may or may not lead to the recipient becoming angry). This inference is different from when the mapping is used in more positive emotions, such as [happiness]{.smallcaps}, where giving or getting happiness suggests causing someone to be happy [@stefanowitsch_happiness_2004; @rajeg_metaphorical_2019].


### [Intensity is quantity]{.smallcaps} {#quantity-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-quantity-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_quantity_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "quantity$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(anger_entity|intensity_entity.amount)"), "key", "no"),
         status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(intensity_entity.amount)") &
                            str_detect(LU, "(beberapa|sebagian dari)"), "no", status))
mapping_quantity_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_quantity_token) %>% 
  mutate(aspects = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(more amount)"), "more", "less"),
         aspects = replace(aspects, str_detect(MAPPING, "entity.amount$"), "neutral"))
mapping_quantity_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'quantity$') %>% left_join(mapping_quantity_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_quantity_token_stats)
quantity_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("quantity$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
mapping_quantity_more_or_less <- mapping_quantity_token_stats %>% filter(aspects != "neutral") %>% group_by(aspects) %>% summarise(n_lu = sum(n_lu), n_token = sum(n_token))
```

This metaphor is based on the [quantity]{.smallcaps} frame and only attested in the corpus dataset. Lakoff & Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987, 200] propose that anger has a quantitative aspect reflecting its intensity, which in turn is conceptualised as an amount. The metaphor is manifested by `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'quantity$')` metaphorical expressions representing `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_mapping', 'quantity$'))` mappings. 

- more amount of entity &rarr; intensified anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_quantity_token_stats, "intensified")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_quantity_token, "intensified", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_quantity_token, "intensified")`

- less amount of entity &rarr; less intense anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_quantity_token_stats, "less intense")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_quantity_token, "less intense", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_quantity_token, "less intense")`

- lessening the amount of entity &rarr; de-intensifying anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_quantity_token_stats, "lessening")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_quantity_token, "lessening", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_quantity_token, "lessening"), fixed("/*decreased*"), "")`
  
- adding more amount of entity &rarr; intensifying anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_quantity_token_stats, "adding")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_quantity_token, "adding", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_quantity_token, "adding")`

- amount of entity &rarr; intensity of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_quantity_token_stats, "entity.amount")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_quantity_token, "entity.amount", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_quantity_token, "entity.amount")`

There are two perspectives in this metaphor, the increased or the lessening amount of the entity. The former highlights the intensification of anger while the latter is for the reduced intensity. There are more types and tokens that reflect the intensification of anger (type=`r pull(filter(mapping_quantity_more_or_less, aspects=='more'), n_lu)`; token=`r pull(filter(mapping_quantity_more_or_less, aspects=='more'), n_token)`; see the first and the fourth mappings) than those for the reduced intensity (type=`r pull(filter(mapping_quantity_more_or_less, aspects=='less'), n_lu)`; token=`r pull(filter(mapping_quantity_more_or_less, aspects=='less'), n_token)`; the second and the third mappings).

### [Marah is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps} {#hotfluid-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-hotfluid-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_hotfluid_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "heated fluid")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "(anger_\\(heated\\-\\)fluid|anger\\-level_fluid\\-heat\\-level|experiencer_container\\-with\\-hot\\-fluid)"), "key", "no"))
mapping_hotfluid_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_hotfluid_token)
mapping_hotfluid_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'heated fluid') %>% left_join(mapping_hotfluid_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_hotfluid_token_stats)
hotfluid_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("heated fluid", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

This central metaphor is shared between the two approaches (rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'heated')` in the lexical approach, and rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'heated')` in the corpus approach). The metaphor has higher tokens, types, and mappings in the corpus dataset.

`r str_replace(paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_hotfluid_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = ""), fixed("(heated )"), "")`

- heated fluid in container &rarr; high intensity of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hotfluid_token_stats, "high intensity")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hotfluid_token, "high intensity", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hotfluid_token, "high intensity")`

- boiling over the fluid to overflow &rarr; intensifying and expressing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hotfluid_token_stats, "boiling over the fluid to overflow")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hotfluid_token, "boiling over the fluid to overflow", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hotfluid_token, "boiling over the fluid to overflow")`

- evaporating liquid &rarr; reduced intensity of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hotfluid_token_stats, "evaporating")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hotfluid_token, "evaporating", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hotfluid_token, "evaporating")`

In both datasets, the [heated fluid]{.smallcaps} metaphor focuses on a heightened intensity of anger. One minor difference is, in the corpus dataset only, there is an attestation of a mapping for the ceasing of anger; this is conceptualised as an evaporating fluid (the last mapping above).

### [Marah is a submerged entity]{.smallcaps} {#submerged-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-submerged-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_submerged_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "submerged")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_submerged_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_submerged_token)
mapping_submerged_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'submerged') %>% left_join(mapping_submerged_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_submerged_token_stats)
submerged_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("submerged", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

On a more general level, the metaphor could be viewed as a sub-case of the generic metaphor [existence is being here]{.smallcaps}, which has a universal perceptual basis (i.e., we know that something exists when it is physically presence and can be seen). The [submerged entity]{.smallcaps} metaphor captures the way anger exists and it is not attested in the lexical approach. The key mapping is `r get_key_mappings(mapping_submerged_token)`. From this mapping, two entailed mappings are postulated based on the semantics of the source frame LUs.

- the presence/emergence/protruding of the entity &rarr; experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_submerged_token_stats, "protruding")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_submerged_token, "protruding", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_submerged_token, "protruding")`

- forcing the entity to emerge &rarr; causing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_submerged_token_stats, "to emerge")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_submerged_token, "to emerge", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_submerged_token, "to emerge")`

The metaphor differs slightly from the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor ([§\@ref(unveiled-tokenbased)](#unveiled-tokenbased)) whereby anger already exists and highlights the issue of whether the experiencer is keen to unveil the anger to others or not [cf. @rajeg_metaphorical_2019, 158]. Compared to the other metaphors discussed so far, [anger is submerged entity]{.smallcaps} is rather conventionalised in its linguistic realisation. It is manifested by small number of types [`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'submerged')`] making up the high token of the metaphor [`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'submerged')`]; that is, only `r get_meta_freq_profiles('submerged', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor_tokenbased, metaphor_var = "cm_broader")[[2]]`% of the metaphor's tokens are of different types that are repeated many times.

### [Marah is a sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} {#sleeping-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-sleeping-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_sleeping_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "sleeping")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_sleeping_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_sleeping_token)
mapping_sleeping_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'sleeping') %>% left_join(mapping_sleeping_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_sleeping_token_stats)
sleeping_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("sleeping", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} metaphor is also attested in the lexical approach though at the lower rank (i.e., `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, "sleeping")`) ([§\@ref(awakening-typebased)](#awakening-typebased)). It is based on the [awakening]{.smallcaps} and the [caused upward motion]{.smallcaps} frames. The utilised aspect of the source frame is causing inactive/calm organisms to become awake/active/alert/aroused. The manner of awakening/alerting can be fishing for the organism via bait. In the target frame, this is mapped onto the cause of anger. This metaphor could be a pre-condition for the danger and fierceness of the organism that needs to be restrained as in the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor ([§\@ref(animal-tokenbased)](#animal-tokenbased)). 

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_sleeping_token), "____ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "")`

- fishing/awakening the calm entity &rarr; causing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_sleeping_token_stats, "awakening")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_sleeping_token, "awakening", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_sleeping_token, "awakening")`

- awaken/alerted entity &rarr; anger near the limit (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_sleeping_token_stats, "alerted")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_sleeping_token, "alerted", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_sleeping_token, "alerted")`

Like the [submerged entity]{.smallcaps}, the [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps} highlights the way anger is brought about. The conventionalised lexical unit of this metaphor is based on the root *pancing* 'lure a fish using a bite; to fish for sth.' and *bangkit* 'wake/get up'.

`r str_replace(paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_naturalforce_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = ""), fixed("(destructive )"), "(destructive) ")`

- being destroyed &rarr; experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "being destroyed")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "being destroyed", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "being destroyed")`

- reducing the amount of the disaster &rarr; causing anger to cease (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "reducing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "reducing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "reducing")`

- ceasing amount of force &rarr; ceasing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_naturalforce_token_stats, "ceasing anger")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_naturalforce_token, "ceasing anger", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_naturalforce_token, "ceasing anger")`
  
The [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor focuses on the intense effect of the natural force, as evident by the productivity of this mapping. This is a more specific way of construing the harmful effect of anger than the other [harm]{.smallcaps}-related metaphor based on different frames within the same family ([§\@ref(harm-tokenbased)](#harm-tokenbased)).

### [Marah is a superior]{.smallcaps} {#subjugator-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-subjugator-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_subjugator_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "subjugator")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_subjugator_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_subjugator_token)
mapping_subjugator_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'subjugator') %>% left_join(mapping_subjugator_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_subjugator_token_stats)
subjugator_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("subjugator", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

The [superior/subjugator]{.smallcaps} metaphor is only attested in the corpus data and based on the mapping of anger onto the Subjugator role in the [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame [cf. @kovecses_metaphor_2000, 21, 70]. Kövecses [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 71] argues that this metaphor involves asymmetric control-relation between the social inferior (the Subjugated role in the [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame), namely the self (or its associates), and the social superior (Subjugator), namely the emotion. The authority element is incorporated into the [servitude]{.smallcaps} frame from the structure of the [authority]{.smallcaps} frame, which is the sub-case of the [control]{.smallcaps} frame. There are `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_mapping', 'subjugator'))` mappings in this metaphor, evoked by `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_type', 'subjugator'))` types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, col_names = 'n_token', 'subjugator')` tokens).

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_subjugator_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "") %>% str_replace(fixed("subjugator"), "superior/subjugator")`

- being subjugated &rarr; effect of and losing control over anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "being subjugated")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "being subjugated", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "being subjugated")`

- exercising domination over the subjugator &rarr; managing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "domination")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "domination", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "domination")`

- inferior object of anger &rarr; angry person (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_subjugator_token_stats, "inferior object")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_subjugator_token, "inferior object", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_subjugator_token, "inferior object"), fixed("(dari)"), "dari")`)

The metaphor focuses on the emotional effect of anger (e.g., being irrational). It is construed via the degree of control and power that the authority has over the subjugated. This aspect is manifested as the metaphor's predominant mapping. There is only a small number of types that evoke the self's attempt to manage anger (i.e., exercise/compromising control).

```{r mapping-biological-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_biological_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'biological entity') %>% left_join(mapping_biological_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_biological_token_stats)
biological_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("biological entity", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```


The [biological entity]{.smallcaps} metaphor has relatively low tokens [`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_token", "biological")`] and sits towards the bottom of the top-20 metaphor (rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'biological')`). However, it is expressed by relatively varied metaphorical expressions (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_type", "biological")` types out of `r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_token", "biological")` tokens) and elaborate mappings [`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, "n_mapping", "biological")`] as presented below. 

- the root/base/seed of an organism &rarr; anger as cause (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "root\\/base\\/seed")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "root\\/base\\/seed", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "root\\/base\\/seed")`
  
- fruits/yields of a plant &rarr; anger as effect (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "fruits\\/yields")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "fruits\\/yields", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fruits\\/yields")`

- the seed/source of an organism &rarr; cause of anger(type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "seed\\/source")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source")`)

-  the growth/birth of the organism &rarr; the existence of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "growth\\/birth")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth")`)

- plants creeping out &rarr; effect of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "creeping out")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out")`)

- fertilising the organism/plant &rarr; maintaining anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "fertilising")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising")`)

No single mapping could be considered predominant. The metaphorical expressions utilise different components of the [organism]{.smallcaps} frame family (e.g., the [plant life cycle]{.smallcaps} and [animate entity]{.smallcaps} frames) to highlight different aspects of anger. Anger can be considered as an effect, or as a cause leading to another effect. The metaphor also includes expressions referring to the cause, existence, and effect of anger.


### [Marah is an (un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} {#unveiled-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-hidden-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_hidden_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "veiled object")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_hidden_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_hidden_token)
mapping_hidden_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'veiled object') %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token_stats)
hidden_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("veiled object", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```


This metaphor is attested in the two approaches and occupies the lower rank in the salience tables (rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'veiled')` in the lexical approach, and rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'veiled')` in the corpus one). [Anger]{.smallcaps} is construed as an object that the experiencer has control over to be displayed (i.e., expressed for others to perceive), or keep it hidden, hence perceptually inaccessible by others. These two inferences, which are re-cast as the mappings in the metaphor, are based on the [hiding]{.smallcaps} and [cause to see]{.smallcaps} frames.

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_hidden_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "")`

- unveiling an object &rarr; expressing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "expressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing")`

- hiding/protecting an object &rarr; suppressing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "suppressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing")`

The focus of this metaphor is on the externalisation or "unveiling" the anger. It is shown by the higher type and token frequencies of this mapping compared to the hiding mapping. In the lexical approach ([§\@ref(hidden-typebased)](#hidden-typebased)), however, the metaphor focuses on the suppression of anger (i.e., maintaining control by "hiding" the object). Overall, the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor highlights the control and expression of anger.


### [Marah is physical contact/harm]{.smallcaps} {#harm-tokenbased}

The [contact/harm]{.smallcaps} metaphor is also attested in the lexical approach and ranks in the top-3 of the salience table ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-type-based)](#metaphor-table-type-based)), not in the corpus-based salience table. The metaphorical expressions evoking the [physical harm]{.smallcaps} frame capture the effect of anger. It impacts both the experiencer and other entities that become the target of angry person, especially when the Harmed_entity role of the frame is filled with entity other than the experiencer of anger. The following mappings are postulated for the metaphor.

```{r mapping-harm-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_harm_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "harm$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_harm_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_harm_token)
mapping_harm_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'harm$') %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token_stats)
harm_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("harm$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_harm_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "")`

- harmful effect (at others) &rarr; effect of anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "harmful effect")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect")`

- physical harm &rarr; experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "experiencing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing")`

In Kövecses's [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000] [force-dynamic]{.smallcaps} system, the metaphor highlights the part where the experience of anger leads to experiencer's responses (e.g., directing the harm at others). This aspect is also an important part of the [anger is a natural force]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(naturalforce-tokenbased)](#naturalforce-tokenbased)), [anger is a subjugator]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(subjugator-tokenbased)](#subjugator-tokenbased)), and [anger is a weapon]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(weapon-tokenbased)](#weapon-tokenbased)) metaphors.

The difference in the two approaches for this metaphor is in the main meaning focus. The predominant types in the lexical approach focus on the cause of anger. The expressions referring to physical touching or harm are used in the context of harming the candidate experiencer (i.e., causing the candidate experiencer to be angry) ([§\@ref(harm-typebased)](#harm-typebased)). In the corpus approach, however, the physical harm expressions are used to show the harmful effect when experiencing anger and when targeting that effect to others.

### [Intensity is luminosity]{.smallcaps} {#luminousity-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-luminousity-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_luminousity_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "luminousity$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_luminousity_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_luminousity_token)
mapping_luminousity_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'luminousity$') %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token_stats)
luminousity_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("luminousity$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

Amongst the metaphors in the bottom five of the corpus-based salience table ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based)), [intensity is luminosity]{.smallcaps} has the highest token (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'luminousity$')`) but also the lowest types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'luminousity$')`) and mappings (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_mapping', 'luminousity$')`). The metaphor is not attested in the lexical approach. Below are the mappings of the metaphor.

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_luminousity_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "")`

- reducing the level of light &rarr; reducing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_luminousity_token_stats, "reducing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing")`

The metaphor is based on LUs evoking the [darkness]{.smallcaps} frame, a perspective of the [luminosity]{.smallcaps} frame that characterises the amount of light from a light source. These frames are utilised in highlighting the ceasing intensity of anger. [Intensity is luminosity]{.smallcaps} is related to the [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(fire-tokenbased)](#fire-tokenbased)) but captures anger's intensity not via the degree of heat, but the amount of light.

### [Marah is a person]{.smallcaps} {#person-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-person-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_person_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "person$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_person_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_person_token)
mapping_person_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'person$') %>% left_join(mapping_person_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_person_token_stats)
person_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("person$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

This metaphor could be viewed as a soft personification of anger and is not attested in the lexical approach. It is based on LUs evoking features of the [person]{.smallcaps} frame, which is a sub-case of the [animate entity]{.smallcaps} and [sentient]{.smallcaps} frames. 

`r paste(paste("- ", unlist(str_split(get_key_mappings(mapping_person_token), "___ ")), "\n", sep = ""), collapse = "")`

- inviting a person &rarr; causing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "inviting")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "inviting", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "inviting")`

- being welcome by/befriend a person &rarr; experiencing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "friend")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "friend", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "friend")`

- dismissing the invited person &rarr; reducing anger (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "dismissing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "dismissing", lu_output = FALSE)`) (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "dismissing")`)

Unlike the other personifying metaphors (e.g., [adversary]{.smallcaps} or [subjugator]{.smallcaps}), [anger is person]{.smallcaps} captures the causation and diminishing of anger, rather than the intensity and effect of it. The metaphorical expressions refer to actions and objectives that animate as well as sentient/cognising entities such as a person typically does. These include welcoming, inviting, dismissing, and befriending or playing with someone. In a way, such actions represent anger as a superficially safe emotion to be with.

## Token-based salience: Metonymy {#tokenbased-metonymy-salience-results}

```{r metonymy-category-tokenbased}
physiological_response_regex <- "(body heat|internal pressure|redness|breathing|visual interference|body hair|teeth biting|foaming)"
metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience %>% 
  mutate(category = if_else(str_detect(METONYMY, physiological_response_regex), "physiological response", "social-communicative behaviour"))

physiology_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category == "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
physiology_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
physiology_type <- c(physiology_type, physiology_type_total)

social_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category != "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
social_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
social_type <- c(social_type, rep("", (length(physiology_type) - 1) - length(social_type)), social_type_total)

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print <- tibble(`social-communicative behaviour:` = social_type, `physiological response:` = physiology_type)
```

The corpus analysis of the metonymy now includes the token frequencies for the metonymies and their type frequencies. These metonymies are rank-ordered in [Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-table-token-based)](#metonymy-table-token-based) by the Aggregate values (i.e., the sums of the values in the “% of all tokens” and “% of all types” columns for each metonymy).


```{r metonymy-table-token-based}
metonymy_tokenbased_salience_print %>% 
  mutate(Metonymy = str_replace(Metonymy, "frustated", "frustrated"),
         Metonymy = str_replace(Metonymy, fixed("speechless"), "inability to speak"),
         Metonymy = str_replace(Metonymy, fixed("visual interference"), "inability to see"),
         Metonymy = str_replace_all(Metonymy, "(?<=for )anger", "marah"),
         Aggregate = replace(Aggregate, is.na(Aggregate), "")) %>% 
  # select(-Aggregate) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Conceptual metonymies for [anger]{.smallcaps} (Token-based, corpus approach)")
```


```{r metonymy-tokenbased-typebased-comparison}
metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared <- intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
metonymy_tokenbased_only <- setdiff(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
metonymy_typebased_only <- setdiff(metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy, metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY)
metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_ALL <- unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
```

From the two datasets, there are total `r numbers2words(length(unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)))` unique metonymies, and most of them (i.e., `r numbers2words(length(intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)))` metonymies [`r round(length(intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy))/length(unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)) * 100, digits = 1)`%]) are shared (cf. [§\@ref(metonymy-compared-both-approaches)](#metonymy-compared-both-approaches) for further comparative discussion). The relatively high number of the shared metonymy types suggests a rather consistent metonymic construal for anger in Indonesian based on data from different approaches.  

### [Strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#verbal-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'aggressive verbal', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy is the most salient in both approaches, having `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive verbal", metaphor_data = FALSE)` and `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive verbal", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the lexical and corpus approaches respectively.

### [Aggressive visual behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#visual-behaviour-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'visual behaviour', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This is another metonymy that is also salient in the two approaches, ranked in the top 3. However, the corpus dataset reveals significantly greater number of types [`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)`] compared to the lexical dataset [`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)`] (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`). From the metonymic expressions above, one does not contain the target term [marah]{.smallcaps} but the sentential context in (@pandangan_liar) clearly indicates that such expression has to do with anger.

(@pandangan_liar) *__Pandangan matanya liar__ dan memancarkan amarah yang meluap.* (ind_mixed_2012_1M: 575480)

In this example, the eyes both spurt out boiled over anger and show wild gaze.

### [Redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} {#redness-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'redness', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy has greater number of types (and thus ranked higher) in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "redness", FALSE)`) than in the lexical one (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_typebased_salience, "redness", FALSE)`) (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`). The metonymic expressions indicate that anger causes such physiological effects of redness in the facial area of the experiencer.

### [Internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} {#internal-pressure-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'internal pressure', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

The [internal pressure]{.smallcaps} metonymy shares the same number of types between the two datasets (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "pressure", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the corpus dataset, and `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "pressure", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the lexical one). The internal pressure predominantly goes with trembling body parts and voice.

### [Body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} {#body-heat-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "body heat", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

The [body heat]{.smallcaps} metonymy is less productive in terms of its type in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "body heat", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types) compared to the lexical one (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "body heat", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types).

### [Violent frustrated behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#frustation-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "violent frustated", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy appears to be less prominent in the corpus dataset than in the lexical one in terms of the number of metonymic expressions and, by consequence, the ranking. In the lexical approach, it is evoked by `r numbers2words(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE))` metonymic expressions (rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_typebased_salience, 'violent', FALSE)`), which is significantly greater than the number of expressions in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, 'violent', FALSE)`) (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`).

### Other singleton metonymies

There are `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2))` metonymies that only have a single type; they are (i) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][1]`]{.smallcaps} (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "crying", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE), "\\s\\[[0-9]\\]$", "")`), (ii) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][2]`]{.smallcaps} (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "foaming", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE), "\\s\\[[0-9]\\]$", "")`), (iii) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][3]`]{.smallcaps} (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "teeth biting", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE), "\\s\\[[0-9]\\]$", "")`), (iv) [`r str_replace(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][4], fixed("speechless"), "inability to speak")`]{.smallcaps} (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "speechless", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE), "\\s\\[[0-9]\\]$", "")`), and (v) [`r str_replace(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][5], fixed("visual interference"), "inability to see")`]{.smallcaps} (`r str_replace(get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "visual interference", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE), "\\s\\[[0-9]\\]$", "")`). Two metonymies have greater number of types in the lexical dataset, namely [inability to see for anger]{.smallcaps} [`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "visual interference", metaphor_data = FALSE)`] and [lip/teeth biting/pressing for anger]{.smallcaps} [`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "teeth biting", metaphor_data = FALSE)`].

## Types of the metonymies (token-based dataset) {#metonymy-category-tokenbased}

From `r nrow(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category)` metonymies, `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response"))` metonymies represent physiological responses (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)`), and `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response"))` are of the social-communicative behaviour types (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token)`).

```{r metonymy-category-table-tokenbased}
metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print %>% 
  mutate(`social-communicative behaviour:` = str_replace_all(`social-communicative behaviour:`, fixed("speechless"), "inability to speak"),
         `social-communicative behaviour:` = str_replace_all(`social-communicative behaviour:`, fixed("frustated"), "frustrated"),
         `physiological response:` = str_replace_all(`physiological response:`, fixed("visual interference"), "inability to see")) %>% 
  rename(`Social-Communicative Behaviour:` = `social-communicative behaviour:`,
         `Physiological Response:` = `physiological response:`) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Two types of metonymies of [anger]{.smallcaps} (token-based dataset)")
```

As in the lexical dataset ([§\@ref(metonymy-category-typebased)](#metonymy-category-typebased)), the number of metonymies in the physiological response category are greater than the ones in the social-communicative behaviour. However, the social-communicative behaviour category in total still exhibits significantly greater number of types (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type$p.value)`) and tokens (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token$p.value)`) than the physiological response category. Therefore, the lexical and corpus-based approaches converge along these distributional aspects of the metonymies.

# Comparison of the results in the lexical and corpus-based approaches

The following sub-sections summarise several points of quantitative and qualitative comparisons between the findings from the two approaches.

## Differences in the number of conceptual metaphors

```{r number-of-metaphors-in-the-two-approaches}
n_cmetaphor_corpus <- nrow(metaphor_salience)
n_cmetaphor_typebased <- nrow(metaphor_typebased_salience)
chisqtest_n_cmetaphor <- chisq.test(c(n_cmetaphor_corpus, n_cmetaphor_typebased))

# difference in the number of metaphors attested only in either approach
n_cmetaphor_lexical_only <- length(metaphor_in_lexical_only)
n_cmetaphor_corpus_only <- length(metaphor_in_corpus_only)
chisqtest_n_cmetaphor_in_either_approach <- chisq.test(c(n_cmetaphor_corpus_only, n_cmetaphor_lexical_only))

```


The obvious difference between the lexical and corpus-based approaches is the potential of the latter to provide a significantly greater number of conceptual metaphors (`r nrow(metaphor_salience)` metaphors) than the former (`r nrow(metaphor_typebased_salience)` metaphors) (*X*^2^=`r round(chisqtest_n_cmetaphor$statistic, digit = 2)`, *df*=`r chisqtest_n_cmetaphor$parameter`, *p*~goodness~~-of-~~fit~`r pval_print(chisqtest_n_cmetaphor$p.value)`).

From the total `r happyr::numbers2words(length(metaphor_typebased_salience$metaphor))` metaphors identified in the type-based, lexical approach ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-type-based)](#metaphor-table-type-based)), `r round((length(metaphor_in_all_database)/length(metaphor_typebased_salience$metaphor)) * 100, digits = 1)`% (i.e., `r numbers2words(length(metaphor_in_all_database))` metaphors) are also attested in the corpus, token-based approach ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based)). These shared metaphors are: `r paste(paste(paste("[", metaphor_in_all_database, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[-length(metaphor_in_all_database)], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metaphor_in_all_database[length(metaphor_in_all_database)], "]{.smallcaps}", sep = ""), sep = "")`. Of these shared metaphors, only `r numbers2words(length(metaphor_in_all_database_top20))` (`r round(length(metaphor_in_all_database_top20)/20 * 100)`%) appear in the top-20 list in [Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based).


The `r numbers2words(length(metaphor_in_lexical_only))` metaphors identified only in the lexical approach (ordered decreasingly by their salience) are `r paste(paste(paste("[", metaphor_in_lexical_only, "]{.smallcaps} (", metaphor_in_lexical_only_aggregate, "%; rank=", metaphor_in_lexical_only_ranking, ")", sep = "")[1:length(metaphor_in_lexical_only)-1], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metaphor_in_lexical_only, "]{.smallcaps} (", metaphor_in_lexical_only_aggregate, "%; rank=", metaphor_in_lexical_only_ranking, ")", sep = "")[length(metaphor_in_lexical_only)], sep = "") %>% str_replace_all(fixed("rough, solid entity"), "a substance") %>% str_replace_all(fixed("degree of control for anger is object dimension"), "degree of controlling anger is the size of patience as a container")`. The remaining `r round((length(metaphor_in_corpus_only)/nrow(metaphor_salience)) * 100, digits = 1)`% (`r length(metaphor_in_corpus_only)` types) of the token-based metaphors are absent from the lexical dataset, which is a significant difference (*X*^2^=`r round(chisqtest_n_cmetaphor_in_either_approach$statistic, digit = 2)`, *df*=`r chisqtest_n_cmetaphor_in_either_approach$parameter`, *p*~goodness~~-of-~~fit~`r pval_print(chisqtest_n_cmetaphor_in_either_approach$p.value)`). The fact that several metaphors are only attested in either approach and that the corpus-based approach offers a higher likelihood to identify more metaphors, showcase the call for combining the two approaches for more comprehensive coverage.

## Differences in the salience of the shared metaphors {#shared-salience-compare}

Another quantitative difference can be inspected among the shared metaphors. Namely, they can differ in their salience values and thus ranking. [Figure \@ref(fig:salience-ranking-comparison)](#salience-ranking-comparison) visualises these differences.

```{r salience-ranking-comparison, fig.width = 10, dpi = 600, fig.cap="Comparison of ranking and salience of the shared metaphors between the two approaches/methods."}
metaphor_salience1 <- metaphor_salience |> 
  mutate(metaphor = str_replace_all(metaphor, "anger", "marah"))
df_token_based <- metaphor_salience1 |> 
  mutate(ranking = 1:nrow(metaphor_salience),
         metaphor = factor(metaphor, 
                           levels = metaphor_salience1$metaphor),

metaphor_typebased_salience1 <- metaphor_typebased_salience |> 
  mutate(metaphor = str_replace_all(metaphor, "anger", "marah"))
df_type_based <- metaphor_typebased_salience1 |> 
  mutate(ranking = 1:nrow(metaphor_typebased_salience1),
         metaphor = factor(metaphor, 
                           levels = metaphor_typebased_salience1$metaphor),
         ranking = fct_rev(factor(ranking)))
df_both <- select(df_token_based, metaphor, aggregate, ranking) |> 
  mutate(method = "corpus_token_based") |> 
  bind_rows(select(df_type_based, metaphor, aggregate, ranking) |> 
              mutate(method = "lexical_type_based")) |> 
  mutate(method = factor(method, 
                         levels = c("lexical_type_based",

df_shared_metaphor <- df_both |> 
  filter(metaphor %in% str_replace_all(metaphor_in_all_database, 
                                       "anger", "marah"))

## visualisation =====
df_shared_metaphor |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = method, 
             y = ranking,
             group = metaphor)) +
  geom_path(aes(colour = metaphor),
            alpha = .7) +
  theme_light() +
  geom_text(data = filter(df_shared_metaphor, method == "lexical_type_based"),
            aes(label = str_replace(metaphor, "(^marah is | of marah)", ""), size = aggregate)) +
  geom_text(data = filter(df_shared_metaphor, method == "corpus_token_based"),
            aes(label = str_replace(metaphor, "(^marah is | of marah)", ""), size = aggregate)) +
  labs(y = "Salience rank",
       colour = "Shared metaphors",

ggsave("results/fig-1.png", 
       width = 10,
       height = 6.5,
       dpi = 600,
```
