```{r salience-ranking-comparison, fig.width = 10, dpi = 600, fig.cap="Comparison of ranking and salience of the shared metaphors between the two approaches/methods."}
ggsave("results/fig-1.tiff", 
       width = 10,
       height = 6.5,
       dpi = 600,
       unit = "in",
       device = "tiff")
```

Clear differences can be seen. For instance, [substance in a container]{.smallcaps} is the most salient in the corpus, token-based approach while the same metaphor is only at rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'is substance in a ')` in the type-based approach. A similar increase in salience from the type-based approach is shown by the [possession]{.smallcaps} and [intensity is verticality]{.smallcaps} metaphors in the corpus, token-based approach. In addition to salience, and hence, ranking increase, there are categorically specific metaphors whose salience values drastically drop in the corpus, token-based data (i.e., from within the top-10 position in the type-based list to outside the top-10 position in the token-based data); they are [physical contact/harm]{.smallcaps} (from the rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'physical contact')` to `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'physical contact')`), [disease]{.smallcaps} (from the rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'disease')` to `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'disease')`), [insanity]{.smallcaps} (from the rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'insanity')` to `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'insanity')`), and [bitterness]{.smallcaps} (from the rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'bitterness')` to `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'bitterness')`). Finally, [Figure \@ref(fig:salience-ranking-comparison)](#salience-ranking-comparison) also shows that [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} and [fire]{.smallcaps} are consistently amongst the most salient metaphors in the two approaches, suggesting their centrality in the cognitive model of [anger]{.smallcaps} in Indonesian; there are also metaphors that relatively consistently occupy the lower half of the top-20 table (e.g., [natural force]{.smallcaps}, [sleeping organism]{.smallcaps}, and [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps}).

Empty labels at rank 4 and 5 in the corpus-based panel in [Figure \@ref(fig:salience-ranking-comparison)](#salience-ranking-comparison) are filled with different metaphors not attested in the type-based, lexical approach, namely [weapon]{.smallcaps} and [adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps} respectively. What is qualitatively interesting is that the focus on overall control over the emotion presented by the [insanity]{.smallcaps} metaphor in the type-based approach is also captured using a different image by the [adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps} metaphor. Similarly, additional metaphor at rank 10 on the corpus, token-based panel attested only in the corpus-based approach, namely [intensity is quantity]{.smallcaps}, expands the intensity focus together with other metaphors in the top-10 list (i.e., [verticality]{.smallcaps} and [substance]{.smallcaps}-related metaphors). In the next section, such a qualitative difference in main meaning focus, due to quantitative difference (i.e., mapping productivity), between the shared metaphor will be discussed.

 
## Differences in the main meaning focus of the shared metaphors

Even though the two approaches share a number of metaphors, the main meaning focus of these metaphors can differ across the two approaches. This is summarised in [Table \@ref(tab:main-meaning-focus-table)](#main-meaning-focus-table) for the shared metaphors in the top 20 list.

```{r main-meaning-focus-table}
tribble(
  ~Metaphor, ~`Lexical, type-based approach`, ~`Corpus, token-based approach`,
  "[fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps}", "aggresiveness of the angry person ([§\\@ref(animal-typebased)](#animal-typebased))", "regulating anger (i.e., restraining the animal) ([§\\@ref(animal-tokenbased)](#animal-tokenbased))",
  "[physical contact/harm]{.smallcaps}", "cause of the anger ([§\\@ref(harm-typebased)](#harm-typebased))", "harmful effect to the experiencer/angry person and to the others/external target ([§\\@ref(harm-tokenbased)](#harm-tokenbased))",
  "[pressurised substance in container]{.smallcaps}", "causing increased pressure and substance ([§\\@ref(pressurised-typebased)](#pressurised-typebased))", "loss of control (i.e., exploding container) ([§\\@ref(pressurised-tokenbased)](#pressurised-tokenbased))",
  "[(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps}", "regulating anger (i.e., concealing the object) ([§\\@ref(hidden-typebased)](#hidden-typebased))", "expressing anger (i.e., unveiling the object) ([§\\@ref(unveiled-tokenbased)](#unveiled-tokenbased))"
) |> 
  knitr::kable(caption = "The main meaning focus of the shared metaphors in the top 20 list.")
```

Such qualitative differences stem from quantitative assessment of the productivity of the metaphorical mappings for the metaphors (i.e., the number of different linguistic expressions manifesting a given mapping) [@kovecses_metaphor_2010, 140]. Another related difference between the two approaches is that for a given shared metaphor, certain mapping is only identified in one of the approaches. This could surely affect the salience of the metaphor. For instance, the mapping expressing the controlling of the substance/emotion is not identified for the [pressurised substance]{.smallcaps} metaphor in the lexical approach but only in the corpus, token-based approach. The same is true for the [heated fluid]{.smallcaps} metaphor, in which an additional mapping unidentified in the lexical approach is present in the token-based approach, namely the ceasing (i.e., decreased intensity of) anger construed as an evaporating liquid.

The two approaches overall should be viewed as complementary in enriching the characterisation of the main meaning focus of a given metaphor.

## Metonymies {#metonymy-compared-both-approaches}

As to the metonymy, most (i.e., `r round(length(metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared)/length(metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_ALL) * 100, 2)`%) of the `r numbers2words(length(metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_ALL))` metonymies from the two approaches combined are shared (as discussed in [§\@ref(tokenbased-metonymy-salience-results)](#tokenbased-metonymy-salience-results)); they are: `r paste(paste(paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[-length(metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared)], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared[length(metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared)], "]{.smallcaps}", sep = ""), sep = "")`. 
This high percentage of the shared metonymies indicates some convergences between the two approaches in terms of the **types** and the salient metonymies for anger. Similar to the metaphor data, there are metonymies that appear only in the lexical, type-based data (i.e., `r paste(paste(paste("[", metonymy_typebased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[1:length(metonymy_typebased_only)-1], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metonymy_typebased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[length(metonymy_typebased_only)], sep = "")`) and in the corpus, token-based data (i.e., `r paste(paste(paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[1:length(metonymy_tokenbased_only)-1], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[length(metonymy_tokenbased_only)], sep = "") %>% str_replace(fixed("speechless"), "inability to speak")`). 

As in the salience comparison of the metaphors ([§\@ref(shared-salience-compare)](#shared-salience-compare)), the metonymy also shows dynamics in their salience ranking across the two approaches (see [Figure \@ref(fig:salience-ranking-comparison-metonymy)](#salience-ranking-comparison-metonymy)).

It is shown that [strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} tops the metonymy tables in the two approaches, but has higher salience value in the corpus, token-based approach (cf. the different font sizes). The prominence of [strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} metonymy corroborates Heider's [-@heider_landscapes_1991, 80, 116] finding that verbal abuse is one kind of reaction of anger (in addition to physical violence).

Another interesting dynamics is the noticeable rise of salience and ranking of the [redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} metonymy in the corpus, token-based data. # Metonymical basis of [anger]{.smallcaps} metaphors {#metonymic-basis}

Three of the five physiology-based metonymies suggested by Lakoff and Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987, 197] motivate the two principal metaphors for anger: [anger is heat]{.smallcaps} and [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps} [see @rajeg_metafora_2013, 211-213, for the quantitative evidence for the prominent status of these anger metaphors in Indonesian]. These three metonymies are [body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(body-heat-tokenbased)](#body-heat-tokenbased) and [\@ref(body-heat-typebased)](#body-heat-typebased)), [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(internal-pressure-typebased)](#internal-pressure-typebased) and [\@ref(internal-pressure-tokenbased)](#internal-pressure-tokenbased)), and [redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(redness-typebased)](#redness-typebased) and [\@ref(redness-tokenbased)](#redness-tokenbased)). In addition to these, there are other physiology-related metonymies ([Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-category-table-typebased)](#metonymy-category-table-typebased) and [Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-category-table-tokenbased)](#metonymy-category-table-tokenbased)) motivating other metaphors. The list below shows the relevant metaphors (from the two approaches) motivated by the physiology-based metonymies.

- [Body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is heat]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is fire]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [intensity is temperature]{.smallcaps} (corpus dataset; outside the top-20 salient metaphors)

The [heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps} may also be motivated by the [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} metonymy [@holland_cognitive_1987, 197], given that internal heat pressure could trigger the boiling over of the heated fluid.

- [Redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is fire]{.smallcaps}
  - [intensity is luminosity]{.smallcaps}

- [Caressing the chest for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(caressing-chest-typebased)](#caressing-chest-typebased)), [lip/teeth biting/pressing for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(lip-biting-typebased)](#lip-biting-typebased)), [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps}, and [breathing difficulty for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(breathing-typebased)](#breathing-typebased)) could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is contained substance]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is pressurised substance in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heat]{.smallcaps}

Caressing the chest represents a gesture that could be interpreted as an attempt to hold the pressing anger inside (hence, an attempt to show patience). The biting/pressing of the lip/teeth could also indicate holding back pressure and pain. Difficulty to breath could be related to raising internal pressure pushing up the lungs.

- [Inability to see for anger]{.smallcaps} motivates the [anger is darkness]{.smallcaps} metaphor.

The social-based metonymies represent what Kövecses [-@kovecses_where_2015] suggests as non-embodied contexts and could motivate these metaphors:

- [Strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} and [Aggressive visual behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps}

  - [anger is fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is weapon]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is (un)veiled object]{.smallcaps}

- [Violent frustrated behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps}; [crying for anger]{.smallcaps}

  - [anger is insanity]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is subjugator]{.smallcaps}

The qualitative analyses above offer some motivation for several metaphors in the top-20 tables of the two approaches. These metaphors are based on characteristics that are metonymically associated with anger.

# Cultural model of [anger]{.smallcaps} {#cultural-model}

The cultural model of anger in Indonesian converges with the five-stage prototypical cultural model of anger (and emotions in general) in the cognitive linguistic literature [@holland_cognitive_1987, 210-214; @kovecses_where_2015, 84-85]. The aspects highlighted by the metaphorical mappings [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 40-46] in the model correspond to the semantic dimensions of emotion from psychological studies [see @soriano_2013 that discusses (di/con)vergence between metaphorical meaning foci of anger and the dimensions of emotions]. For instance, the Intensity aspect [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 41] corresponds to the dimension of Arousal [@soriano_2013, 415-416]. The Negative/Positive (or [Un]desirability) aspect [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 44] corresponds to the dimension of Valence/Pleasantness [@soriano_2013, 417]. The cultural model of the concept [anger]{.smallcaps} in Indonesian unfolds as follows:

Stage 1: cause of anger (offending event)

The Causation aspect is an addition to Kövecses's [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000] list of aspects [see @soriano_2013, 416]. It provides the reason why anger exists. This aspect is predominantly construed as metaphorical events (see the list below, such as igniting fire, disturbing dormant animal, pulling the trigger), or a constant state of affairs (e.g., annoyance) [ @soriano_2013, 416; see also @heider_landscapes_1991, 81, finding that the cause of anger can be indicated by the "annoyance" cluster that he proposes]:

- 

    - annoyance
    - disturbing/harming dormant animal
    - touching/harming a person
    - pulling the trigger
    - igniting fire
    - inviting a person
    - seed/source of an organism

Stage 2: anger exists

The existential stage of anger contains three aspects: Intensity, Evaluation, and Harm. They could be metaphorically captured in two different ways: (i) separately by different mappings from a single metaphor (e.g., the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor can capture the Intensity and Harm aspects) [@soriano_2013, 415-418], or (ii) exclusively by one metaphor (e.g., the [darkness]{.smallcaps} metaphor only captures the negative Evaluation aspect). It is at this stage that anger exerts force on the experiencer (i) to become emotional, (ii) to experience the harmful effect of the force and exhibiting various physiological responses as shown by the metonymies, and eventually (iii) to attempt a retribution/reaction [@holland_cognitive_1987, 214; @kovecses_where_2015, 84-85] (see stage 5 below).

- aspect: Intensity

    The prototypical model of emotion postulates that, at this stage, the intensity tends to escalate and reach the limit the self can control [@kovecses_where_2015, 85]. The following mappings capture the Intensity:

    - fullness of, and increase pressure to, the substance
    - high degree of fire, and level of heat in the fluid
    - more quantity
    - aggressive behaviour and the attack of the animal
    - degree of effect of physical harm
    - amount of natural force and strength of effect
    - (extent of the) insane behaviour

- aspect: Evaluation 

    The Evaluative aspect of anger is prototypically negative [@soriano_2013, 416]. This includes the danger and unacceptability of the angry reaction to others and the self. They are metaphorically construed as:

    - bitter taste
    - being in the dark
    - intrinsic negative effect of the disease
    - strong and destructive natural force as an intrinsically negative force
    - affected/impeded motion and being confined

- aspect: Harm

    The Harm aspect relates to the psychological harm to the self and others. It is construed as the effect of physiological harm via the [emotional harm is physical damage]{.smallcaps} metaphor [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 46], which is inherited by the more specific metaphorical mappings as follows:

    - danger of the adversary's attack
    - harmful effect of physical harm, disease, and destructive natural process
    - aiming weapon at others
    - insane behaviour
    - harm of the attack by the aggressive animal

Stage 3: attempt at control

Following the force-dynamic schema of emotion metaphors [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 62-63], the rational self demonstrates a force tendency towards calmness. In doing so, the self attempts to resist and/or counterforce the emotional forces, including regulating the felt intensity and/or the expression (losing control of) emotion [@soriano_2013, 417]. This stage is captured by these mappings:

- 

    - restraining captive animal
    - suppressing/impeding substance or fluid from going out
    - hiding the object
    - combating the opponent
    - avoiding confinement/impediment
    - maintaining sane/calm behaviour

If all the above attempts were successful and anger ceased before the self lost control, it would represent the non-prototypical model of anger scenarios: "Successful suppression", "Spontaneous cessation", and "Terminating event" [@holland_cognitive_1987, 215].

Stage 4: lacking and losing control

When the force of anger is too strong to control, the experiencer eventually loses control. That aspect is captured by the following metaphorical mappings:

- 

    - insane behaviour
    - reduced dimension of an object (shortage of emotional control/patience/calm)
    - being subjugated as an inferior object
    - losing/giving in to the adversary
    - unleashing the fierce, captive animal
    - unveiling the hidden object
    - explosion of the pressurised container
    - boiling over the heated fluid to overflow
    - being ravaged by the destructive natural force

The aspects Difficulty to cope and Passivity are also represented in this stage since loss of control over forces implies difficulty in counter-forcing them, resulting in the self being passive to the force (e.g., being subjugated, losing, being ravaged).

Stage 5: act of retribution

This stage represents the Desire to act (to others) aspect: a reaction as "a result of the emotion itself" [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 45; @soriano_2013, 417], rather than the desire to possess anger. Metaphorical expressions from the following mappings differently capture construal of expressing and directing the anger towards the wrongdoer (retribution) or other parties.

- 

    - releasing/channelling out the fluid at others
    - aiming the weapon at others as targets, and punishing others with the weapon

Lakoff and Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987, 214] propose that "redirected anger" (i.e., non-retributive to the wrongdoer) is a non-prototypical extension. Below are examples of the redirected anger from the above mappings: 

(@chanelling_out_model) `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(NODE_SENTENCES)` (`r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(FILES)`: `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(SENT_ID) %>% as.character()`)

(@retribution_model) `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(NODE_SENTENCES)` (`r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(FILES)`: `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(SENT_ID) %>% as.character()`)

The connection between the metaphor and the stages of the model tends to be one to many, as demonstrated by Soriano [-@soriano_2013] and earlier by Lakoff and Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987]. A metaphor does not exclusively contribute to one stage, but plausibly to different stages of the model. This is because the metaphorical mappings for a given metaphor refer to different aspects corresponding to certain stages in the model. For instance, the [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor has the mapping for the cause of anger (igniting the fire) (stage 1), the intensity of anger (high degree of heat) (stage 2), and intrinsically the danger of high extent of fire to the self and others (enacted at stage 5). Similarly, metaphorical mappings within the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor consist of, among others, restraining the animal captive (an attempt at control; stage 3), unleashing the captive animal (loss of control; stage 4), which can manifest in different reaction to the self or others (stage 5), and the attack of the animal to the victim that has implication to the harm aspect of anger [cf. @holland_cognitive_1987, for the contribution of the [heated fluid]{.smallcaps} metaphor to the different stages of the model].

# The role of context {#contexts}

## Situational context {#situational-context}

Kövecses [-@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 217-218; -@kovecses_metaphormindcontext_2019] proposes three sub-types of the situational context: the physical environment, the social situation, and the cultural context.

Geographically, Indonesia is the largest archipelago in the world, lying across the Equator and between the Indian and Pacific oceans. It has a relatively even tropical climate year-round with two seasons, dry and wet. Geologically, Indonesia is located at the "Pacific Ring of Fire" (PRoF) [@britannica_ring_2020; @masum_pacific_2019]. The PRoF refers to a geographical area with "high volcanic and seismic activities within the edges of the Pacific Ocean" [@masum_pacific_2019, 1], meaning that it is "a site for frequent earthquakes and powerful volcanic eruptions" [@masum_pacific_2019, 1]. These two natural forces could be accompanied with the tsunami (warning) [cf. @reid_history_2015]. There are more than 100 active volcanoes from the west to the eastern parts of Indonesia [@masum_pacific_2019, 3; @siebert_volcanoes_2011]. 

Such salient geographical and geological landscapes of Indonesia could motivate the use and comprehension of these metaphors: [natural force]{.smallcaps}, [fire]{.smallcaps}, [heated fluid]{.smallcaps}, and [temperature/hot-cold]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *kemarahan berubah __dingin__* 'anger becomes *cold*', *aku __kepanasan__ amarah* 'I *suffer the heat of* anger'; also in [§\@ref(heat-typebased)](#heat-typebased)). This study and Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013, 110-111] found singletons of expressions specifying anger as (lava in a) volcano, a sub-case of [heated fluid]{.smallcaps} metaphor: _**gunung api** kemarahan_ '*volcano* of anger' ([§\@ref(hotfluid-tokenbased)](#hotfluid-tokenbased)), _kemarahan seperti **lahar**_ 'anger be like *lava*', _**memuntahkan lahar** amarah_ '*puking the lava* of anger', and _amarah bagai **kepundan gunung**_ 'anger be like the *(lava) crater of mountain*' [@rajeg_metafora_2013, 110-111]. Moreover, the PRoF environment could motivate the [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor, evoked predominantly by expressions from the [natural disaster]{.smallcaps} and [destructive natural process]{.smallcaps} frames ([§\@ref(naturalforce-tokenbased)](#naturalforce-tokenbased)) [see also @fox_body_2018, 137, who found the construal of anger as a storm arising in the person in Rotenese of Eastern Indonesia; and @rajeg_metafora_2013, who found a statistical association between [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor and anger]. Another piece of evidence to link anger and its negativity to the destructive natural force comes from Reid's [-@reid_history_2015] historical study, which identified several uses of the phrase *gempa bumi* 'earthquakes lit. quake earth' and related expressions from the Malay Bible in the [*Malay Concordance Project*](https://mcp.anu.edu.au) [@reid_history_2015, 66]. These expressions are used to represent earthquakes as manifestations of the wrath of God, and omens (following venerable Islamic and pre-Islamic local beliefs); Reid [-@reid_history_2015, 66] further notes that description about earthquakes appear prominently in the chronicles of Java and Bali, suggesting the long-standing awareness of such context of Indonesia physical environment. 

From the socio-cultural aspect, Indonesian tends to emphasise non-individualistic/group affiliation and social solidarity. This reflects Indonesia's deeply rooted socio-cultural legacy called *gotong royong* 'lit. work together' [@simarmata_gotong_2020]. Such social-cultural consideration gives rise to the importance of empathy and the concealment of emotion in the social context [@heider_cultural_2011, 10-11; @fox_body_2018, 137]. To maintain social harmony, concealment of emotion and reconciliation should be the primary goal, rather than hostile confrontation and aggressive expression. Such regulation of emotion is also related to politeness that can benefit social interaction [@prastuti_adaptation_2020]. This is consistent with Heider's study on Minangkabau and Javanese Indonesian speakers who "mask most anger, and the open expression of anger is strongly disapproved of and negatively sanctioned" [@heider_landscapes_1991, 80]. This context motivates the use of metaphors highlighting the attempt at emotional control and expression, such as the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor [see also @matsuki_1995, 149, for similar socio-cultural context in Japanese to suppress their anger]. In Rotenese of Eastern Indonesia, the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor is part of "ritual admonitions" offering counsel on anger (and other emotions such as fear, shame, and doubt), where the addressee is told not to reveal anger in the neck [@fox_body_2018, 136]. In addition to the metaphor, social-communicative behaviour metonymies, especially those denoting the expressive behaviours of anger, could also be motivated by the socio-cultural aspect.

## Discourse context {#discourse-context}

```{r surrounding-discourse-code}
marah %>% filter(duplicated(SENT_ID), USE == "metaphor") %>% pull(SENT_ID) -> dup_sent_metaphor
marah %>% filter(duplicated(SENT_ID)) %>% pull(SENT_ID) -> dup_sent_metaphor_metonymy
mixed_metaphor_patterns <- marah %>% filter(SENT_ID %in% dup_sent_metaphor) %>% arrange(desc(SENT_ID), CM_BROADER) %>% select(SENT_ID, FILES, NODE_SENTENCES, MP, MP_GLOSS, CM_BROADER) %>% group_by(SENT_ID, FILES) %>% mutate(n_metaphor_per_sentence = n_distinct(CM_BROADER)) %>% ungroup() %>% group_by(SENT_ID, FILES) %>% mutate(n_pattern_in_sentence = n()) %>% ungroup()
mixed_metaphor_metonymy_patterns <- marah %>% filter(SENT_ID %in% dup_sent_metaphor_metonymy) %>% arrange(desc(SENT_ID), CM_BROADER) %>% select(SENT_ID, FILES, NODE_SENTENCES, MP, MP_GLOSS, CM_BROADER)
```

One aspect of the discourse context is the "surrounding discourse", that is, how the cotext/linguistic context of the previous discourse influence, or is related to, the production of metaphor in the following discourse [@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 218-219]. One example is the use of similar conceptual metaphors in multiple constructions (e.g., noun phrases and argument-structure constructions) that are combined into a single utterance (typically at the sentence level) [cf. @sullivan_frames_2013 for the interplay between grammatical constructions and metaphor].  

(@discourse_ctx_fire) _Wajahnya yang riang menjadi **kemerah-merahan** karena **nyala** **api** kemarahan yang **membakar** dadanya_ (ind_mixed_2012_1M: 376378).

Example (@discourse_ctx_fire) illustrates the combination of a metonymic pattern (in the main clause) and two metaphorical expressions for [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} (within the subordinate clause marked with *karena* 'because'). The use of [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor in the noun phrase _**nyala api** kemarahan_ '*flame of the fire of* anger' could influence the forgoing discourse in the relative clause construction _kemarahan yang **membakar** dadanya_ 'anger that *burns* the chest'. In the context of the sentence, the two metaphorical expressions emphasise the specific reason for the metonymy [redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} used in the preceding, main clause. Let us see another example of [anger is substance in a container]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(contained-substance-tokenbased)](#contained-substance-tokenbased) and [§\@ref(contained-substance-typebased)](#contained-substance-typebased))


(@discourse_ctx_substance) _Jika amarah tersebut tak **tersalurkan** atau ternetralisasi dengan permintaan maaf atau jiwa besar mengikhlaskan, yang akan terjadi selanjutnya adalah amarah itu **mengendap** dan semakin **mengeras** dalam batinnya._ (ind_newscrawl_2016_1M: 343033)

Sentence (@discourse_ctx_substance) contains more than one metaphorical expression that indicates a sequential, cause-and-effect scenario all within the same metaphorical frame, namely the [contained substance]{.smallcaps}. The sentence talks about the conserving effects of anger-substance if not being channelled out in the form of apology and big-heartedness. This shows how the use of a given metaphor in the preceding discourse indicating an inability to channel out and neutralise anger, which is the cause, could influence the reasoning for the ensuing discourse indicating the effects of such cause using the same metaphor (i.e., becoming solidified and hardened inside).

## Conceptual-cognitive context {#conceptual-context}

One aspect of the conceptual-cognitive context hinted at by Kövecses [-@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 219-220; -@kovecses_metaphormindcontext_2019] is the **conventionality** of a given metaphor:

i.  the conventional association between a given source and target domains in the metaphorical conceptual system, and

i.  the conventionalised source-domain expression used to talk about certain aspects of the target domain. 

For the first point, Kövecses mentions [life is a journey]{.smallcaps} and [argument is war]{.smallcaps} metaphors with the conventional relationship between their source and target domains in the long-term memory of the speakers. In the case of anger in Indonesian, Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] has identified which source domains are statistically associated with anger (compared to the other emotions) ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)). This statistical association between the two domains could be assumed to reflect their conventional association, which needs further experimental verification. In addition to using statistical association to assess a metaphor's conventionality, Lakoff and Turner [-@lakoff_more_1989, 55] propose that a conceptual metaphor is considered conventionalised in language when "it underlies a range of everyday linguistic expressions". This proposal suggests the role of type frequency (i.e., the number of linguistic-types manifesting a metaphor) in measuring conventionality.

For the second point, Kövecses argues that the verb "defend" from the [war]{.smallcaps} domain is a conventionalised expression to express the meaning 'supporting an argument' (as in "*defending* an argument") in the target domain of [argument]{.smallcaps}. From the corpus-based perspective, the conventionalised linguistic expressions for a given aspect of, or meaning in, the target domain could be identified from the expression's frequency of occurrences in the corpus (e.g., how many times does a given source-domain LU, compared to the other, is used for a given aspect or meaning of the target) [see @stefanowitsch_words_2006, 68]. As an illustration, the most frequent (and potentially the default choice of) LU to express the causation aspect of anger via the [fire]{.smallcaps} frame ([§\@ref(fire-tokenbased)](#fire-tokenbased)) is based on the verb root *sulut* 'kindle/ignite', as in _**menyulutkan** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*kindle*/*ignite* anger' (45 tokens), rather than _**memantik** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*light up* anger' (3 tokens) or _**mencetuskan** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*ignite/light up* anger' (2 tokens).

Another type of conceptual-cognitive context is ideology, particularly religious ideology. Religious ideology and belief in Indonesia are very strong. They have long been an integral part of Indonesian daily, socio-cultural life, since it is listed as the first principle in the nation's ideology *Pancasila* ('The Five Principles'), namely belief in the Supreme God. From the religious and spiritual perspective, anger is generally viewed negatively and dangerous [@bhide_anger_2007; @faizah_how_2021; @minhas_spiritual_2017]; this provides a plausible grounding for metaphors focusing on the negative valence and danger, namely [adversary]{.smallcaps}, [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps}, [subjugator]{.smallcaps}, [disease]{.smallcaps}, [darkness]{.smallcaps}, [insanity]{.smallcaps}, [evil creature]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *massa sudah __dirasuki__ amarah* 'the masses has been *possessed* by anger'), and [deceiver]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *__tipuan__/__godaan__ amarah* '*trickery*/*enticement* of anger') [@soriano_anger_2003, 118 also argues for the religio-cultural influence of Christianity on construing anger as [devil]{.smallcaps} in Spanish]. For instance, as a Balinese Hindu, in my elementary-school religion subject, I was taught that anger is one of the six enemies, the so-called *Sad Ripu* ('Six Enemies'), that humans need to manage or even defeat. This is a religious basis for the use of [adversary]{.smallcaps} and [subjugator]{.smallcaps} metaphors in construing anger [see also @faizah_how_2021 for the view from Islam; and @minhas_spiritual_2017, from the multi-religion perspective]. Moreover, the devastating effects of anger have been illustrated in various parts of the famous Hindu epic, the *Mahābhārata* [@bhide_anger_2007]. Another example is the religious-ideological view of anger as a disease, which is reflected in the notion of "Spiritual healing or medicine" [@minhas_spiritual_2017]. Such a healing can also be used, among others, for "anger management" and (literally) can "prevent the impact of disease by reducing bad feeling or anger" [@minhas_spiritual_2017, 168].

## Bodily context {#bodily-context}

```{r bodily-context}
non_bp <- c("jiwa", "pikiran", "batin", "ekspresi", "raut", "akal", "kalbu", "mental", "tatapan", "diri")
bp_meta_freq <- marah %>% 
  filter(!BODY_PART %in% non_bp, !is.na(BODY_PART)) %>% 
  count(BODY_PART, CM_BROADER, sort = TRUE)
bp_freq <- bp_meta_freq %>% 
  group_by(BODY_PART) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(n)) %>% 
  mutate(eng = c("liver", "eyes", "chest", "heart", "crown of the head", "face", 
                 "head", "brain", "body", "mouth", "hand(s)", "body")) %>% 
  select(BODY_PART, eng, n)
```

The bodily context is related to the locus of emotion, which is in turn rooted in the cultural situation and pre-modern religious practices in Indonesia. This study found that *hati* 'liver' is the predominant body-part term (`r pull(filter(bp_freq, BODY_PART == "hati"), n)` tokens) used as locus of emotion in a variety of metaphors (*X*^2^=`r round(chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$statistic, digit = 2)`, *df*=`r chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$parameter`, *p*~goodness~~-of-~~fit~`r pval_print(chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$p.value)`)^[The other body-part terms used in the metaphorical expressions are as follows (together with their token frequencies): `r bp_freq %>% filter(BODY_PART != "hati") %>% mutate(bp_eng_freq = paste("*", BODY_PART, "* '", eng, "' (", n, ")", sep = "")) %>% pull(bp_eng_freq) %>% paste0(., collapse = ", ")`.]. Siahaan [-@siahaan_did_2008] proposes that the liver divination ritual and the ethno-religious belief of *hati* 'liver' as the locus for the living soul could be the underlying cultural motivations for the importance of *hati* in the conceptualisation of emotion and cognition in Indonesian. This shows the sociocultural situatedness of embodiment in metaphorical conceptualisations of anger.

# Conclusions {#conclusions}

From combining the lexical (type-based) and corpus linguistic (token-based) approaches, this study reveals the dynamics (i.e., convergence and divergence) in the metaphors and metonymies of [anger]{.smallcaps} and their degree of salience. Metaphors attested in the lexical and the corpus-based approaches may differ in several respects. One example is in the different main meaning focus of the same metaphor in the two approaches, due to different productivity and presence of a given metaphorical mapping (e.g., the [pressurised substance in a container]{.smallcaps} and [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphors). Another example is the attestation of metaphors only in either approach. Such differences would also result in different degree of salience and ranking of the same metaphors.

This study also found that the metaphors strongly associated with anger in Rajeg's [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] corpus-based study ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)) also make into the top-20 salience tables (i.e., the family of the [pressurised and heated substance]{.smallcaps}, the [heat/fire]{.smallcaps}, and the [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphors), even though the relative salience of the metaphors in this study is contrasted for their occurrences with anger only (rather than with other emotions as in Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] and Stefanowitsch [-@stefanowitsch_words_2006]). This study also offers new insights regarding the salient metonymies for anger in Indonesian that are not discussed in previous studies ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)). Overall, the salience-based analyses offer a different perspective in capturing the prominence of metaphors and metonymies for anger by taking into account the central components of metaphor and metonymy in CMT, namely the extent of mappings and the linguistic expressions. 

Furthermore, the Indonesian prototypical cultural model of anger is largely correspond to the five-stage model proposed in previous work on anger in American English [@holland_cognitive_1987], and capture relevant semantic dimensions of emotions proposed in the psychological literature [@soriano_2013]. This study also identified examples of non-prototypical model of anger, such as the redirected anger and the metaphor suggesting concealment. 

Finally, this study argues for the different contexts as the motivating factors in the uses of several metaphors of anger. These contexts include the geographical and geological landscapes of Indonesia, the deeply rooted socio-cultural and religious beliefs of Indonesian, the conventional metaphors in the memory, and the socio-cultural situatedness of embodiment for the bodily locus of anger. The contextual dimension of metaphor usages is the missing aspect of previous works on anger metaphors in Indonesian.
